response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the presence of a human seated with their neck exposed. The robot is positioned to interact with the neck. The environment appears to be a standard workspace.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The robot's wrist frame is aligned such that its X, Y, and Z axes roughly correspond to the right, up, and forward directions relative to the human's frame, respectively.
The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward and backward motion relative to the person's neck, with positive Z being forward into the neck and negative Z being away from the neck.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move cyclically forward and backward against the neck to provide massage.
The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion to the right or left relative to the person's neck, with positive X being to the right.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move cyclically right and left across the neck to provide massage.
The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward and downward motion relative to the person's neck, with positive Y being upward.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move cyclically up and down to apply pressure and massage the neck.
To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved cyclically along all three linear axes, with variations in pressure (Y-axis) and lateral movement (X-axis) and penetration (Z-axis) to simulate a massage.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: The human neck is composed of muscle and bone, and covered by skin. Estimated mass interacting with the gripper is 2 kg. It is relatively soft and compliant. The gripper will grasp the neck applying some force to hold the neck.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity will act on the neck, but the person is assumed to be sitting upright, so gravity's effect is minimal in terms of the applied forces. Friction between the gripper and the neck skin will need to be considered. There are no external hinges or resistance to motion.
- The relevant object is the human neck, which is soft and deformable, has mass 2 kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.7.
- The surface of interaction is the skin and muscle of the neck which is soft. The surface of the neck has a static friction coefficient of 0.7 with the object.
- Contact Types: The robot will maintain a pinch grasp on the neck, requiring force to maintain. The robot will be maintaining surface contact, and avoid edge contact.
- Motion Type: The motion involves pushing, sliding, and slight tapping.
- Contact Considerations: Force is required in all three linear axes to achieve the massage.
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts motion in a combination of linear and rotational fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z] axes.
- Task duration: The task motion is cyclic. Task duration will be set to 30 seconds.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: mass = 2 kg, friction coefficient = 0.7, g = 9.81 m/s^2.
- Relevant equations: F_friction = mu * F_normal
- Relevant assumptions: We assume a static friction coefficient adequately describes the friction.
- Computations: The normal force is roughly the grasping force. To slide the hand across the skin we need to overcome the friction with a reasonable force of around 5N. The force of gravity on the neck is 2kg * 9.81 m/s^2 = 19.62N.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 2 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.7 along the surface: The force to overcome friction is 0.7 * 5 N = 3.5 N

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon applying massage strokes, the object in the image must exert positive and negative force along the X-axis with magnitude 5 N.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon applying pressure during the massage, the object in the image must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 10 N.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon applying forward pressure and motion on the neck, the object in the image must exert positive and negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude 5 N.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon there not being significant rotational requirements on the neck, the object in the image must exert no torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon there not being significant rotational requirements on the neck, the object in the image must exert no torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon there not being significant rotational requirements on the neck, the object in the image must exert no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Grasping force: The estimated force range to maintain a grasp on the soft, pliable neck, while allowing for sliding, is between 5 to 10 N, thus 5 to 10 N .

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The human neck is a soft, pliable structure with an estimated mass of 2 kg and a static friction coefficient of 0.7 with the gripper."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "The robot must move cyclically along all three linear axes, with variations in pressure (Y-axis) and lateral movement (X-axis) and penetration (Z-axis) to simulate a massage."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [5, 10, 5]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [5, 10, 5, 0, 0, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 7.5
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 30
```

[end of motion plan]

The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!

3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."

5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
